channel.title: Bubble Graphics
channel.description: Graphic Design Portfolio of Claire Hughes - London based graphic designer / visual communicator.

item.title: Bristowe Retirement Apartments
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

To re-brand and re-establish the Bristowe Retirement Apartments as a relaxing. friendly and comfortable home for independent seniors.

Concept

Taking inspiration from the calming seaside location and the overall eclectic, art nouveau style of the Bristowe building and gardens; I designed the imagery to reflect a sense of elegance and home comfort. The very evident art nouveau styling you experience when entering the reception area of the building I implemented as the core theme of the Bristowe's new brand. For example: the sunbeam pattern of the buildings stained glass windows became the key brand elements used throughout their corporate stationery and promotional material.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded: Hello I'm Claire, A full-time senior designer for a lively media and advertising agency in East London. Working across different media formats for print and online, I'm passionate about producing creative, clean and effective design while also pushing myself that one step further with every project I undertake. Clients and other creatives love working with me because I communicate their briefs clearly to produce work that surpasses expectations and keeps clients happy. I am focused on getting details right without being an overbearing task master and prefer to give space for creativity to develop when building new concepts, brand communications and advertising. I lead by example to deliver kick ass design work. I am constantly searching for inspiration in everything that surrounds me, shapes, sound, colour, environment, people, art, beautiful landscapes, buildings and adventures, cycling somewhere around London or checking out colourful second-hand markets. Though my acoustic guitar skills have got pretty rusty, I like singing out loud sometimes (but not if anyone around me has a pressing deadline approaching). Awarded a D&AD In-Book Prize in the area of Brand-Communications and Advertising, I am keen to enter further competitions. If you have any questions about my work or would like to chat about a project, I would love to hear from you! so feel free to get in touch.

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:

item.title: D&AD 2010/Metro
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

Create a transport advertising poster campaign and strapline that cuts through the visual noise of the everyday commute to promote Metro newspapers.

Our transport advertising poster campaign: Are you bored talking about the weather?

The Metro is full of interesting, bite sized stories about different subjects. We thought that when commuters arrived to work they wouldn’t need anymore small talk such as talking about the weather. Through reading the Metro newspaper, they would have heaps of interesting information to discuss instead. As a team we wanted the poster campaign to read one after the other so that the target audience would naturally make the association between the three posters which follow the strapline ‘no more talking about the weather’.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A Transport Advertising Poster Campaign for Metro.

item.title: D&AD 2011/IE9
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

Internet Explorer is back. Re-establish the brand for the re-imagined, redesigned and rebuilt Internet Explorer 9 (IE9).

Our advertising / branding campaign for the new IE9 browser

By being forward-thinking and keeping up to date with emerging trends, a galaxy of colourful Internet Explorer 9 icons were created. These icons are 3D and dynamic in their appearance. Our planet icons were designed to resemble a glass ball similar to a marble containing the letter ‘e’. The letter ‘i’ is depicted on the outside of the ball as a reflection of light. As Windows Internet Explorer is commonly abbreviated to IE we decided to adapt this as part of its more contemporary approach to the future. The overall concept will allow users to focus on both interactions and colours, and not be distracted by overly bright hues. Technology is moving on towards the future and our aim is to encourage the user to move forward into the future too by simply upgrading to the IE9 browser.

item.title: Order of Service
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

A simple but elegant order of service within a conventional wedding aesthetic to complete the wedding stationery pack.

Concept

Using a selective wallpaper design swatch, I based the inside cover around this design to reflect the brief and the convention suggested above.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A simple but elegant order of service within a conventional wedding aesthetic.

item.title: ISTD2011/On Yer Bike
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

We were given a selection of ISTD student competition briefs to choose from where we could choose to enter the competition and in which case follow the exact typographic requirements the brief had set. Or instead choose to complete the brief independently for example; to use any media that will work, the choice was ours. I chose to complete the brief independently and selected the brief 'On Yer Bike'. An information system for cyclists to find their way around cities.

Concept

Turning 'On Yer Bike' into a conceptually based project, I decided to focus on user-centered design as a research method where I took into consideration the level of safety being offered to each cyclist. From this I created ahierarchy of colour coded routes to aid cyclists in the city that would offer safer, shorter and more appealing journeys.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An information system which aids cyclists in the city. Offering safer, shorter and more appealing journeys.

item.title: New From Old/Spam
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

New From Old – We were given a redundant product to research and were asked to re-brand it and to create a new context for it that would celebrate its usefulness and set it alongside similar contemporary items.

Concept

For this project I chose to re-brand and package the existing product Spam. Through researching into their long brand history dating back to 1937, I noticed a certain level of existing continuity throughout their design such as the curved rectangular shaped can, the complimentary blue and yellow colours and the Spam logo. The only alterations to their design during this period were for their 60th anniversary and for a special edition Spamobile range. Although Spam had become extremely popular during world war two as well as having sold over 7 billion cans to date, Spam isn't as popular within families now as it was previously. My aim was to make Spam popular within families again, therefore I chose to re-brand the product to appeal to todays generation of school children and their parents. To best appeal to this generation I created a series of cool (special edition) monster characters named 'Spamonsters' in vibrant colours with the idea that they would be suitable or school children and their lunchboxes.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A re-brand and package for the existing product Spam.

item.title: Grizzly Grill
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

To re-brand the existing family run Ross-on-Wye pub 'Prince of Wales'  located in Cheltenham UK to become the first of a chain of 'Grizzly Grill' pubs with the aim to attract more families to come and try their new menu.

Concept

Grizzly Grill was a fun name to work with and from this I had the idea of producing a fun and friendly grizzly bear character, that would seem content in sniffing the aroma of food coming from the new Grizzly Grill menu. This would become the main logo mark for the new brand, helping to attract more families to come and try their new menu.  I chose to collaborate with freelance illustrator (friend) Katerina Chou, to help with the creation of the friendly grizzly bear character which I then developed to become the main logo. This logo was later used throughout all other supporting advertising and promotional material.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Grizzly Grill Pub - Freelance identity and branding project.

item.title: Beach & Body Pitch
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

The existing logo was out of date and did not project the brand values and image of Beach & Body. An improved identity was required with a more feminine, fashionable and fun approach.  The target audience consisted of women aged 35 - 65, living on the south coast, having aspirations of glamour. They seek swimwear and accessories for holidays, cruises, as well as local beaches and sports centres. The client particularly liked the the nineteen thirties style of the iconic female swimmer diving.

Concept

A nineteen thirties feminine yet contemporary style of Beach & Body's new brand/identity was created as a pitch. I chose to use the colours blue and yellow to represent golden sand and sunny skies and as well as implementing the female swimmer diving I also chose a clear and contemporary nineteen thirties style font.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Beach & Body Pitch. Logo/brand identity for an independent female swimwear shop.

item.title: Serenity Property Development
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Brief

To design a luxurious brochure which best reflects the new property development 'Serenity'; Serenity has a large lounge opening onto an extensive sun terrace, kitchen/family room, cinema room, gymnasium, sauna and five bedrooms all en-suite. Serenity with its wonderful woodland setting provides the concord of indoor and outdoor living.

Concept 

Serenity is one of many beautifully designed homes built by Britannia Property Group. The brochure design reflects upon the properties name 'Serenity' which denotes a state of quality of being serene and in this instance tranquil and homely.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Serenity; A property development brochure design.

item.title: Scope Charity
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
A self-initiated project. An advertising campaign for 'Scope' raising awareness of the charity as a whole and what they do with regards to helping those affected by Cerebral Palsy. A major value for Scope is to promote equality amongst disabled and non-disabled people within the community.
To do this I focused on three main aspects which included an advertising campaign raising the awareness of independent living, a t-shirt design for the volunteering staff and a re-usable collection sack which would replace normal plastic collection bags, as they were often disposed of without being used.
Scope’s recently designed logo has a symbol of equality inverted into the word Scope. I aimed to further develop their brand throughout the advertising campaign to promote more clearly the variety of services they provide, including assistance and advice with housing. For the campaign I decided upon a motivational strap-line ‘Lets work together’ encouraging people to work together to help the charity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Scope Advertising Campaign. Raising awareness of equality for those affected by Cerebral Palsy.

item.title: PollenLITE
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
About

Inviting hay fever sufferers aged 18 - 65 to take part in the PollenLITE clinical research trial and test a new kind of vaccine that could potentially ‘switch off’ the allergic reaction to grass pollen thereafter.

Brief

Create a new brand identity including name made up of acronyms to promote and to encourage the registering of eligible recipients for this hay fever study.

Concept

The concept was to communicate a happy and warm summertime, without focusing on the negative effects of hay fever such as sneezing. The imagery reflects people enjoying the warm, sunny weather outside and amongst grass and trees. The logo identity reflects summertime through the use of shape and colour with a link to wasps and honeycones, known to be common during the summer months. The style of the new brand is vibrant, fun and contemporary to suit it's intended target audience.

item.title: Tony Robbins
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
About

A FREE workshop to be hosted in London and lead by the American motivational speaker  - Tony Robbins.

Brief

Keeping existing brand consistency, create a direct response landing page, using call to action to encourage it's users to register for the FREE workshop today! • Landing Page • Thank you for registering page • Mobile landing page • Supporting Press Advertisements

item.title: Puerto Vallarta Real Estate
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
About

Puerto Vallarta Real Estate is one of the city's oldest real estate companies. It has successfully been operating since 1981. PV Realty was consecutively chosen by Multi List Vallarta as the number one selling and renting agency in all of Vallarta, Mexico.

Brief

Refresh and re-design a new up-to-date and more user friendly website. Making it easy for the user to browse the list of luxurious properties available.Ensuring the style consistently reflects the long-standing reputation and professionalism in renting and selling luxurious properties in Mexico.

Concept

Taking inspiration from the luxurious holiday feel of the extensive image gallery of  properties, for rent and for sale, I chose to adapt the natural cream coloured buildings and glistening turquoise outdoor swimming pools into the colour palette and simplistic and corporate design of the new website.

item.title: EDAS Charity
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
About

A successfully won pitch, requesting a total re-brand for the leading, Dorset based charity - Essential Drug and Alcohol Services (EDAS).

Brief

To re-design a new logo reflecting the charity including it’s many different services. A new brand identity that can work across supporting printed literature, marketing material and signage as well as a new website.

Concept

The concept was to visually represent the positive, forward thinking charity and its many different training programmes through a new brand identity. With the use of vibrant positive colours that can later be used as colour coding throughout the charities marketing literature to help aid the training programmes organized for users and other local charities. The new logo identity depicts the different training paths through the use of colour and abstract shapes. These shapes resemble moving, growing, learning and positive outcomes. The logo is contemporary in style to reflect the charities established reputation of being leaders in their field and forward thinking.

item.title: Creative Insights
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
Creative Insights is the culmination of a project I undertook with one goal in mind: to try to make landing that elusive first job a less daunting experience for soon-to-be graduates in the design industry, but also for other creative industry graduates. Using Twitter, I asked industry professionals one question:
“If you could give one insight to a soon-to-be design graduate trying to land their first job in the industry, what would it be?”
With an amazing number of responses, I gathered over 50 invaluable insights from design professionals, including Erik Spiekermann, Wolff Olins, Ogilvy Action, USTWO™, Onedotzero, BBH London, D&AD, Grafik Magazine, Penguin Books, Futurebrand and the BBC among others. I presented the gathered insights as direct quotations in the form of an interactive website thecreativeinsights.net along with visual insight cards.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Want to work in the creative industry? Get interactive, first hand advice from industry insiders!

item.title: 30th Birthday Gift
item.dc:creator: bubblegraphics
item.content:encoded:
About

For a good friend's 30th birthday, I wanted to create something memorable, something that would communicate his personality, fun-up-to-date experiences, hobbies and interests but also to give him a gift that he could keep for years to come.

Brief

To gather a collection of icons, that resemble our friend's life up-to-date and to organise these icons into the shape of 30. Delivering the final artwork suitable for screen-printing.

Concept

The concept was to communicate an enjoyable 30th birthday in a personalised and thoughtful manner and in a way that best suited our friend’s own fun style, up-to-date experiences, hobbies and interests. To be presented as a screen-printed, framed keepsake gift.
